definition: Moving a lot or doing many things; in grammar, the active voice names the doer of the action.
examples: He lives an active life and cycles to school.
In the active voice, the subject does the action.

definition: To greatly surprise or impress someone.
examples: The magician’s trick astounded the audience.
Her progress in maths astounded her teacher.

definition: To be present at; to pay attention to; to take care of.
examples: Most students attended the assembly.
Please attend to the instructions carefully.

extra.memory_tip: Attend = ‘at end’ point you show up.

definition: To feel or show great love for something; to keep a hope or idea in your mind.
examples: They cherish family traditions.
She cherished the dream of becoming a doctor.

definition: A written or spoken agreement; to become smaller or shorter; to make an agreement.
examples: She signed a one-year contract. (noun)
Muscles contract when you lift weights. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: CON-tract is a deal; con-TRACT pulls in.

definition: Very keen and excited to do something.
examples: The class was eager to start the experiment.
He gave an eager nod.

definition: To uncover or reveal; to put someone or something at risk by leaving it unprotected.
examples: The report exposed the problem with the pipes.
Too much sun can expose skin to damage.

extra.memory_tip: Expose = take off the ‘pose’ and show the truth.

definition: Elegant movement or kind behaviour; a short prayer; to make something more attractive.
examples: She skated with grace and control. (noun)
Flowers graced the stage. (verb)

definition: To force a rule, tax, or punishment to be obeyed; to put a burden on someone.
examples: The council imposed new parking rules.
I don’t want to impose on your time.

extra.memory_tip: Impose = in + pose the rule onto others.

definition: Not talking proudly about your abilities; simple or small in size or amount.
examples: Despite winning, she remained modest.
They live in a modest house.

extra.memory_tip: Modest = moderate in looks and words.

definition: Side by side and always the same distance apart; something similar; to be similar to.
examples: The two roads are parallel. (adjective)
There are many parallels between the stories. (noun)

extra.memory_tip: Parallel lines run together without meeting.

definition: To make a person or thing unable to move or act.
examples: The venom can paralyze small animals.
Fear can paralyse decision-making.

definition: A person who expects bad outcomes or focuses on the negative.
examples: The pessimist predicted rain for the picnic.
Don’t be a pessimist—give it a try!

definition: To say a poem, list, or story aloud from memory.
examples: We will recite our poems at assembly.
He recited the times tables perfectly.

definition: To say or do something as a reaction to something else; to answer.
examples: Please respond to the email by Friday.
Plants respond to light by growing toward it.
